feed.title: Current watches, warnings, and advisories for United States land zones

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued February 4 at 2:04PM CST by NWS Grand Forks ND
entry.summary: Windy conditions Thursday afternoon and evening; following snowfall on Wednesday of 1 to 3 inches, leads to the chance for blowing and drifting snow impacts for eastern North Dakota and portions of northwestern Minnesota. Periods of reduced visibility down to a quarter of a mile or less is possible during the afternoon and evening hours Thursday. Uncertainty in the strength of winds and the blowability of the snowpack across the region. Be prepared for the chance of impacted travel conditions Thursday afternoon and evening.
entry.cap:areaDesc: West Polk; Norman; Clay; Kittson; West Marshall; Towner; Cavalier; Pembina; Benson; Ramsey; Eastern Walsh County; Eddy; Nelson; Grand Forks; Griggs; Steele; Traill; Barnes; Cass; Western Walsh County

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued February 4 at 12:58PM MST until February 5 at 6:00PM MST by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary:
...RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT FROM LATE WEDNESDAY MORNING THROUGH EARLY WEDNESDAY EVENING FOR MUCH OF NORTHEAST AND EAST CENTRAL NM DUE TO VERY LOW HUMIDITY AND WINDY CONDITIONS...
.Strong and gusty westerly downslope winds will develop late Wednesday morning east of the Sangre De Cristo and Sandia Mountains to the TX and OK borders, peaking during the mid- afternoon when humidity will fall into the single digits in many areas. Winds will diminish during the evening hours. High temperatures will challenge daily record values in this area as well.
The National Weather Service in Albuquerque has issued a Red Flag Warning...which is in effect from 10 AM to 6 PM MST Wednesday. The Fire Weather Watch is no longer in effect.
* AREA AND TIMING...Northeast Highlands (Zone 123), Northeast Plains (Zone 104), Central Highlands (Zone 125) and the East Central Plains (Zone 126) from late Wednesday morning through early Wednesday evening.
* 20 FOOT WINDS...West 20 to 30 mph with occasional gusts to between 40 and 45 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...Minimum values between 8 and 12 percent.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northeast Plains; Northeast Highlands; Central Highlands; East Central Plains

cap:parameter.value: RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT FROM 10 AM TO 6 PM MST WEDNESDAY

entry.title: Flood Watch issued February 4 at 11:55AM PST until February 4 at 8:00PM PST by NWS Eureka CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...A portion of northwest California, including the following areas, Northern Lake and Southern Lake.
* WHEN...Until 8 PM PST this evening.
* IMPACTS...There will be an increased risk of rock and land slides along roadways. Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Creeks and streams may rise out of their banks. Flooding may occur in poor drainage and urban areas. Storm drains and ditches may become clogged with debris. Extensive street flooding and flooding of creeks and rivers are possible.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Heavy rainfall with an atmospheric river will be possible on Tuesday. An additional 1 to 2 inches of rainfall will result in rapid rises on creeks and streams. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northern Lake County; Southern Lake County

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 8 PM PST THIS EVENING

entry.title: Ice Storm Warning issued February 4 at 2:49PM EST until February 6 at 7:00AM EST by NWS Baltimore MD/Washington DC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Significant icing expected. Total ice accumulations between two and three tenths of an inch. Winds gusting as high as 35 mph.
* WHERE...In Virginia, Western Highland County. In West Virginia, Western Pendleton County.
* WHEN...From 7 AM Wednesday to 7 AM EST Thursday.
* IMPACTS...Power outages and tree damage are likely due to the ice. Travel could be nearly impossible. The hazardous conditions could impact the Wednesday morning and evening commutes.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...A mix of light freezing rain, sleet, and snow begins Wednesday morning. Precipitation mainly becomes a steady freezing rain Wednesday night. Temperatures will warm Thursday morning transitioning freezing rain over to rain.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Western Highland; Western Pendleton

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued February 4 at 11:40AM PST until February 5 at 10:00AM PST by NWS Reno NV
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Hydrologic flooding caused by excessive rainfall and snowmelt is ongoing.
* WHERE...A portion of northeast California, including the Susan River and tributaries in Lassen County.
* WHEN...Until 1000 AM PST Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Additional rainfall this afternoon and evening may lead to secondary rises on already high rivers and streams and exacerbate ponding in poor drainage areas. While no additional flooding is forecast for the Susan River, a second rise to minor flood stage can't be ruled out if rain/snow elevation is higher than expected.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1134 AM PST, Rain and snowmelt may cause minor flooding. - More significant flooding is forecast for the Pit River in Northwest Lassen County. See the separate flood warning for additional details on the Pit River. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Eagle Lake, Termo, Bieber, Herlong, Nubieber, Doyle, Susanville, Spaulding, Aspen Grove Campground, Standish, Janesville, Madeline, Crater Lake Campground, Westwood, Pittville, Chilcoot-Vinton, Hallelujah Junction, Eagle Campground, Merrill Campground and Ravendale. - Go to CNRFC.NOAA.GOV for river forecast updates. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lassen, CA

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 10 AM PST WEDNESDAY

entry.title: Flood Warning issued February 4 at 11:34AM PST until February 6 at 12:00PM PST by NWS Reno NV
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Moderate to Major Flooding is ongoing.
* WHERE...Along Pit River and tributaries in Northwest Lassen County including Big Valley, Bieber, and Nubieber.
* WHEN...Until noon PST Thursday.
* IMPACTS...Moderate to major flooding from the Pit river and tributaries are currently impacting Northwest Lassen County. Inundation and damage to roads, agricultural areas, and low lying homes and structures in Big Valley including Bieber and Nubieber. The water level as of Tuesday morning in Bieber is slightly lower then the February 2017 crest.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1128 AM PST, The Pit River near Canby is forecast to peak near major flood stage Wednesday. Impacted areas in and around Bieber are about 30 miles downstream of the stream gage with numerous tributaries in between. River levels in and around Bieber are expected to remain at very high for several days and increasing flows from Canby maybe counterbalanced somewhat by decreasing flows from lower tributaries. - Check cnrfc.noaa.gov for updated river forecasts. The CNRFC will update forecasts 4 times per day by 9am, 3pm, 9pm, and 3am through Tuesday night. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Nubieber, Bieber, Pittville and Ca 299 At Shasta-Lassen Co Line. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lassen, CA

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL NOON PST THURSDAY

* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring.
* WHERE...Eel River at Fernbridge.
* WHEN...Until Wednesday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...At 20.0 feet, Significant flooding of the western portions of Cannibal Island Road, Camp Weott Road, the Salt and Old Rivers, and all adjacent low-lying areas. Flooding in these areas is exaggerated when crest timing is coincident with high tides and strong onshore winds, and for longer duration events. A Special Action Advisory is being issued to all owners of livestock in low-lying areas of the Eel Delta. Owners of livestock should consider taking appropriate action to protect livestock.

It will then fall below flood stage late this afternoon to 18.5 feet just after midnight tonight. It will rise to 19.7 feet late tomorrow morning. It will then fall again and remain below flood stage. - Flood stage is 20.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 20.6 feet on 02/16/1982. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Avalanche Watch issued February 4 at 7:05AM MST by NWS Missoula MT
entry.summary:
AVAMSO
The following message is transmitted at the request of Flathead Avalanche Center Hungry Horse MT.
...AVALANCHE WATCH ISSUED BY THE FLATHEAD AVALANCHE CENTER...
06:47 MST Tue Feb 04 2025 The Flathead Avalanche Center in Hungry Horse has issued a BACKCOUNTRY AVALANCHE WATCH for the following areas:
NWS Missoula MT - MTZ001 (MTZ001)...MTZ002 (MTZ002)
* WHAT...Very dangerous avalanche conditions may develop as a complex winter storm brings heavy snow and powerful winds to the region.
* WHERE...Mid- and upper-elevation slopes in the Swan Range, Whitefish Range, Flathead Range, and portions of Glacier National Park.
* WHEN...In effect from Tue 06:47 MST to Wed 06:47 MST.
* IMPACTS...New and drifting snow may build thick slabs over weak old snow. Human-triggered avalanches are likely on or below steep slopes.
* PRECAUTIONARY / PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...Be alert for changing conditions and increasing avalanche danger. Avoid traveling on or below steep slopes. Shooting cracks and blowing snow are clear signs of danger.
Consult http://www.flatheadavalanche.org/ or www.avalanche.org for more detailed information.
Similar avalanche danger may exist at locations outside the coverage area of this or any avalanche center.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Kootenai/Cabinet Region; West Glacier Region

entry.title: Avalanche Warning issued February 4 at 5:57AM PST by NWS Reno NV
entry.summary:
AVWREV
The following message is transmitted at the request of the U.S. Forest Service Sierra Avalanche Center.
BACKCOUNTRY AVALANCHE WARNING
IMMEDIATE BROADCAST REQUESTED
06:00 PST Tue Feb 04 2025
The Sierra Avalanche Center in Truckee has issued a BACKCOUNTRY AVALANCHE WARNING for the following areas: NWS Reno NV - NVZ002 (Greater Lake Tahoe)... CAZ072 (Greater Lake Tahoe (CA))
* WHAT...The avalanche danger will be HIGH in the backcountry Tuesday through early Wednesday morning.
* WHERE...Central Sierra Nevada Mountains between Yuba Pass (Hwy 49) on the north and Ebbetts Pass (Hwy 4) on the south, including the greater Lake Tahoe area. This does not include ski areas or highways where avalanche mitigation programs exist.
* WHEN...In effect from Tue 06:00 PST to Wed 04:00 PST.
* IMPACTS...Dangerous avalanche conditions exist in the mountains due to heavy snow,rain on snow, and strong winds. Widespread avalanche activity is very likely. Avalanches large enough to bury or injure people are expected.
* PRECAUTIONARY / PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...Traveling in, near, or below backcountry avalanche terrain is not recommended.
Consult https://www.sierraavalanchecenter.org/ or www.avalanche.org for more detailed information.
Similar avalanche danger may exist at locations outside the coverage area of this or any avalanche center.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Greater Lake Tahoe Area; Greater Lake Tahoe Area

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued February 4 at 5:44AM PST until February 5 at 3:00AM PST by NWS Eureka CA
entry.summary:
...INTERMITTENT PERIODS OF HEAVY SNOW THROUGH THE WEEK...
.A prolonged atmospheric river event will continue through much of the week. Snow levels are currently above 3500 feet, but will rapidly drop below 2000 feet Monday through midweek as a cold front crosses the area. Snow levels will first drop along the North Coast and gradually spread south and inland. Overall snowfall will be inconsistent with breaks between distinct snow showers through Tuesday. There is potential for heavier low elevation snow later in the week.
* WHAT...Snow expected for elevations above 2000 feet. Total snow accumulations between 3 and 8 inches on high peaks. Highway pass elevations including much of highway 36 will most likely to see snow late tonight into Tuesday morning with snowfall of 1 to 4 inches on roadways.
* WHERE...Southern Humboldt Interior and Southern Trinity.
* WHEN...Until 3 AM PST Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult. Chain restrictions may be implemented for high elevations.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Snow levels will stay low through the week with potential for heavier snow Wednesday and Thursday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Southern Humboldt Interior; Southern Trinity

entry.title: Flood Warning issued February 3 at 11:10PM PST until February 5 at 10:00PM PST by NWS San Francisco CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Urban areas and small streams flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...A portion of northern California, including the following county, central Sonoma.
* WHEN...Until 1000 PM PST Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is imminent or occurring. Streams continue to rise due to excess runoff from earlier rainfall. Low-water crossings are inundated with water and may not be passable.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1105 PM PST, gauge reports indicated heavy rain. Flooding is already occurring in the warned area. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain have fallen. - Additional rainfall amounts of 4 to 5 inches are possible in the warned area. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Santa Rosa, Rohnert Park, Windsor, Sebastopol, Cotati, Larkfield-Wikiup, South Santa Rosa Cdp, Forestville and Graton. - CGNC1 - Colgan Creek near Sebastopol and GRQC1 - Green Valley Creek at Martinelli Road are rising to Moderate Flood Stage. In addition, MWEC1 - Mark West Creek near Mirabel Heights is forecast to reach Moderate Flood Stage by Tuesday night. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Sonoma, CA
